message: @kennethreitz: http://github.com/explore
Oh, you mean a more customizable profile page
Example queries and what you'd expect to see are always helpful
Featured Projects.
Just curious
Ah you mean inside of a repository?
Hah, repository search is a hard problem.
yeah
just want people to see my real projects before they see me editing my dotfiles

@kneath Oh, yeah... I think my complaint is pretty simple, actually. Use case: Type my JIRA ticket number into the search box.. Fail (cause it only searches source code, not commit messages).. But NOW I'm presented with a drop down (code, commit messages, author, committer).. So I choose commit messages and wha-la.

Mailing lists for projects! I feel like people use Issues when they know there's a bug but there's nowhere to discuss a project to determine if there is a bug (unless people setup Google Groups -- which sucks).
I mean as far as making the whole thing really good, it's very basic right now and extremely resource intensive
@kennethreitz +1
@phil Do you have any specifics? (I'm not saying our current search is great, it's just that search is a vague term)
e.g. projects I flag as 'featured' on my profile show up a the top of the list
Much better search.

@kneath I don't know of any way to get to that screen without failing a search first :| Seems like the first search box ought to either search across everything (then let me limit).. or I ought to see that combo box in the first place.. no?
oh, yeah. inside a repo.. most of my github use is for my startup's private repo.
I have two or three projects i want people to see when they land on my profile, before they see the others i have pushed to recently
which is why we can't offer it on public repos, which sucks
Well it's appreciated. Thanks.
It's definitely not unnoticed

I'm curious why it's tough though.. since you already have a repo-search form that has a combo box, I'd settle for a navigation fix that just allows me to get to that form without failing a search first

another pet request would be to enhance the graphs, and make them branch-aware.. our testers/PMs would dig being able to use something like the imact graph to get a rough sense of what's going on in a branch.
A bit more than one commit
gotcha. well I'm sure you'll get around to it sooner or later.. you guys did hire all those new githubbers!
pro-rated billing, so I dont end up loosing $7 if I upgrade now after the charge hit my card today (which I need :/)
@kneath I'll quite happily trade you a case of beer for a commit on this one :)
Okay, okay.. I'll send a bit more than a case of beer :)
visualizations are fun :)

I'd like to be able to do a `git push` from GitHub's online editor. Currently I can edit the file and save/commit it, but there's no `git push` - which is especially limiting for GitHub Pages sites. This addition would let me use GitHub/Jekyll as a CMS with non-technical folks.
ability to open a pull request as a solution to an existing issue
Pages should be rebuilt on commit @sumeetjain
definitely wasn't for quite some time
Just tried it - you're right. That's really exciting. Do you know if that's a fairly recent change?
I know we had a bunch of bugs related to that have cropped up from time to time, but it should have always been that way
google analytics - http://support.github.com/discussions/feature-requests/660-add-google-analytics-id-to-user-accounts
It would be nice if this got bumped up the list: "Unwatch repo from dashboard" (http://support.github.com/discussions/feature-requests/654-unwatch-repo-from-dashboard)
stars/bookmarks for projects. I'm watching so many projects I'd rather have bookmarked, as I am not interested in every commit/wiki edit/issue on these.
@mrtazz pinboard.in ? :P

Watching projects is broken right now and doesn't give me a sense of what's important and happening right now. This should be removed or replaced with something that scales to more than two or three projects.
Ability to re-open tickets. Even if it's just the project owner or a contributor.
this is typical of developers, no talk in the "remove" sister topic but a lot of chatter on this one =]
CODE REVIEW. DO IT.
@jonesy have you seen the latest pull request improvements? GitHub is the best code review tool around https://github.com/features/projects/codereview
If you guys don't think we have code review, I don't know what to say anymore
@jonesy Pull requests are insanely awesome, and you can commit on diffs/lines in a diff, so I'm not sure what else you'd want for code review.
ie: I want to know that ry/node had 30 commits, 7 pull requests and 9 comments. I don't want 46 entries in my feed for it.  Similar with per user.
@kneath The one thing that's really missing for me is aggregation on the feed.
I mocked up a design in photoshop for you guys and attached it to a ticket somewhere in the bowls of the bug tracker.
not that you want that level of perscription.. but just to get my idea across.
Some more love for the API. Last I checked there were still some "coming soon" sections.

it's really weird that the compare view isn't exposed in more places. like in a repo commit history and also the commit history for a specific file, being able to arbitrarily diff commits would be super handy.
I would love to see better integration between Issues and Wiki. Make [[Wiki Page]] in issue link to wiki page, make #123 in wiki link to issue. Also add ``` code blocks to issues.
I guess the trac/wikipedia/etc-style double row of radio buttons down the left side is a bit too ugly, but there must be some way of doing it
@rbates the gollum wikis are intended to be portable, so use generic markdown instead of github-flavored markdown.
The inbox / notification center could use improvement: searching, sorting, tagging, "promote to issue [in project]"...

@kennethreitz yeah I thought about saving them to my pinboard. But somehow that doesn't feel right to me. If I am interested in a project on github, I want to have it there. I don't want to have my/watched/forked repos in my github dashboard and starred repos somewhere else. Also pinboard is hardwired in my brain for webpages. Maybe I'm weird that way. :)

In the issues screen, when we add an issue, it's weird that we can't add a label to the item. We need to first create the item, then add the label. Sadly, if we click on one label on the right, it totally discard the current item and switch page.. losing all changes.
better navigation. some times, links positions are too smart

I have a two-part but still sort of single request: (1) I would love to be able to delete gists from the overall "My Gists" view (http://cl.ly/56l1) and (2) I would love to be able to unstar starred gists. (I have a handful of starred gists that were deleted by their owners, but I can't seem to shake them.) Anyhow, it's all about better gist-handling.
@franckcuny +1 to activity stream API or a Dashboard page I don't have to manually refresh all the time
anchors on headers in other peoples' READMEs
http://rtomayko.github.com/rocco/
...so I can link to a header
...and to make it so other people link 'em, too, a TOC (probably hidden by default) or a link that appears when hovering over a header, like docco has with paragraphs
Any particular features you're looking for?
Issue tracking needs some love (a lot of love)
@bat Yeah I love docco styles so much
@bat +1 to links to headers, great for Stack Overflow answers

We have to strip the ID attributes from all tags so that clashes don't break any javascript.  I'd like to sit down and add something to automatically generate anchors for all headers, regardless of the format.  It's on the list.
Marking notifications as read when I read them in my email client (with a tracking pixel in the email?)
stars/bookmarks for repos (and profiles) - https://github.com/blog/744-today-s-outage#comment-9094
S/FTP deployments (as in beanstalkapp)

Repo Templates for things like service hooks, so you load up a template and it has your CI system hooks in, Campfire hooks, deployment hooks (I have a system which on a push to production it automatically updates code across servers)
are all ready and set up in the new repo
@NARKOZ you mean push to GitHub with FTP?
@_jared, how about CVS an RCS support?
feature: typing "user/repo" into the searchbox autoredirects you to there
/s/an/and/
SVN support.    j/k
:cry:
Yeah, we hear that a lot
FTP support :D
@NARKOZ: Does beanstalk just sftp new files every time you push?

I may be doing something wrong, but I wish "switch contexts" was a bit more 'sticky'.

If I switch contexts, click a repository in the sidebar, then click the name of the enclosing group in the header, I'm sent to the public face of the group, not the one I saw just after switching contexts.
fwiw clicking the github logo will bring you back to the org dash
@kneath ah! problem solved :-)
@kneath yes, but you can set different branches and servers (eg prod/dev). You may also change deployment mode (manual/auto).
Bookmarks for repos. Sometimes I don't want to really watch a repo but want to remember it somehow.
Natively found in every browser shipped the past decade, built into every website and sharable across many devices
http://share.kyleneath.com/captures/Window-20110313-205217.png
I actually found this pretty awesome feature
There's even startups based around it like http://pinboard.in
Having been forced to implement (and maintain) a bookmarks system inside a webapp before, it is (almost?) never worth the trouble.  It's an attractive idea, but ... no...
But he's right. ;)
Quite a bit of sarcasm there @kneath. :-P
Code review like in google code.
Google code doesn't offer code review
Our Pull Requests are pretty awesome though, you should really check them out. Best code review on the planet as far as I'm concerned.
so, why stars on gists? you can just bookmark them.
As a big-time Watcher, I'd like to have only-shown-to-me tagging of users and projects. "German coders", "Coders w/o glasses", or "anti-pattern-projects" could then all become browsable realities.
I know is a long shot, and it doesn't go with the name. But I would like Mercuarial support at github :)
Does http://gist.github.com allow cloning push/pull over http/https?
please improve message/notification UX. they suck right now. there's no way to delete them all with a single click, etc... etc...
@aseba GitHub supports Mercurial: http://hg-git.github.com/
@klauem: Good question. If it doesn't, it should.
Increase collaborator limit in Micro plan from 1 to 2 (or even 3).  I keep running into team sizes of 3 instead of 2...
grep in source trees
Timeline
is it exposed in the API?
checkout counts. Followers are nice but I'd like some way to anonymously determine unique checkouts.
@lusis There were clone stats in the past. Sadly they're gone now, though.
Good question. Clone stats would be awesome. I'll check the API.

Maybe I'm just being silly and this already exists. Is there a simple way to message all private collaborators of a repo? I end up just sending e-mails but the github markdown additions are always sadly missed when I do.
No, there isn't right now
i miss clone stats
A good issue tracker
@kneath Every change can be reviewed in google code
@vega113: I feel like you haven't use GitHub
Check it out. You can comment on any commit, any line on a pull request. Pretty much anywhere you see a diff, you can comment.
@technoweenie Holly crap I Will definitely take a look at that!
besides the current file/folder browsing, implement GithubFinder.  Combining with the "t" shortcut, Github will be invincible!
You can also comment on other people's comments.
A "twitter list" like feature for repos?
Add ability to create new files on Github. Would like this for occasional use with Jekyll.
@ryanf Use the URL as an API... you can compare any commitish with any other commitish in your repo: http://hile.mn/gd1Xg6

I'd like to see a smarter feed, but I'd settle for a more granular feed. I'm only really interested in some projects when they release a new version, so I'd love to only receive tag notifications. Some projects are noisy, so I don't care as much about every comment, but issues and pull requests are still important. Seeing "x is following y" rolled up into aggregate trends would make it *more* useful to follow more people, rather than diluting the value by creating a bunch of noise.
I'd like to have the option of seeing the activity feed "by time" like now or rolled up by user (recent actions by each user) or rolled up by project (recent actions by any user on that project)
What about an option to keep my fork's master branch up to date with any upstream changes automatically?
@knoopx you can try this gem - https://rubygems.org/gems/github-shush
label sets/templates for issues
Would be nice to bookmark projects, separately from watching them
incremental revision id : branch_name + `git log branch_name --oneline | wc -l` == hashid
a way to describe branches, without having to create a "README update" commit
@alexg0 a separate project, but try http://codeshelver.com/

@bobthecow oh, I know, I actually wrote a little userscript to compare two revisions in the /commits view, but it shouldn't take so much digging to find a feature that is immediately visible in, say, trac

Given a file in a source tree, show me all the versions of it across forks on github, highlighting the most popular changes. Sort of like a distributed blame. Use case is when you're thinking about making a small change and you're wondering if anyone has done it already and in what context (commit message, etc.).
Have any idea how you might measure popularity?
the # of forks it's been merged into? might not be much to show now, but it might change user behavior

A nicer way to "browse" the network graph to see which forks implement what features would be nice. Having to scroll, hover over a point, rinse, repeat is sort of annoying compared to just reading a list per fork. Then again, for highly-forked projects, showing lists would be a UI nightmare… but that's why we have you, @kneath :P
Also, very minor, but live preview when editing (list of accepted README formats) would be rad. I usually end up having 5 "Formatting" commits until I get the syntax/looks of the readme right.
+1 to README preview
Also I would like that when seeing a file it recognizes Emacs or Vim mode types to display the file with the proper syntax highlight

Finally I've got an idea what's missing: A sort of reminder to update your forks. Especially pull requests should have some indicator that they're outdated (and thus will not be easily mergeable). I know this might not be easy to implement, but I think it would help improve the flow of contributions.

When viewing diffs a lot of times you just want to see a little more context around whatever line or lines of code were changed ("what method is this even in?!"). You should make a thing that "expands" the # of lines of code shown (without a new page load)
An addon to my request above would be to allow users to update their forks using a single click on a merge/rebase button.

Some way of making the activity stream less of a firehose, possibly by grouping similar events, turning some events into collapsed one-liners. Related: some way to bookmark/star projects that you aren't interested in watching the activity on but still want to remember to look at occasionally.

I would like "Issues" that show up on Google search results to actually show up when I click through to the Issues page. It's the most frustrating thing when I get a hit on Google that's a listed issue on a github, but I can't actually find the result when I click through to the issues page.
+1 for emacs / vim mode types.  I know it's a non-trivial problem, but it'd be super cool.
@kneath I wish you could comment on compare views (that aren't pull requests)... I keep expecting to be able to do that.
I'd love to see all refs in a single view (à la gitk)

It would be sweet if you could perform searches across forks of a given project (both commit messages and code). Bonus points for rolling up results that occur in multiple forks with an indicator of how many forks the identical commit or source code is present in.
The one feature that I think is missing from Github is a bookmarking feature, by opposition to the watch feature. I am watching a lot of repos that I don't really want to watch but just bookmark...
It would be cool if, on a repo's contributors page, the people were broken up into groups: Committers (those with commit access to the repo) and Authors.
The ability to search commits in a repository. Useful, for example, to find when a method was introduced if the project documentation doesn't track that very well.
As I wrote here https://convore.com/github/listing-contributions/ the ability to see a user's contributions to other projects.
Textmate's "Find in Project".
Search in issues...
I'd really love organisation private gists

A usable issue tracker would be wonderful. What do I mean with usable? I can't assign tickets to users, I can't assign tickets to versions, I can't filter by multiple tags, I can't exclude by tags, as soon as you have 20+ issues the list becomes completely unhelpful, sometimes even the title is removed by the tags (see issue 740 on divio/django-cms), search doesn't work, the tags make the issue list odd to read, as maintainer I can't properly priorize issues,.... TL;DR: Make it *simpler* and *cleaner*, don't make everything a tag. I can't believe that github, that made so many things so awesome (pull request) can make something as unuseful as the issue tracker. /endrant

One issue feature I'd love to see is auto-search when adding an issue. Use the title (and maybe the content) of a new issue and automatically perform a search as the user is adding the issue to look for possible duplicates. Assuming the search works.
@pvande Is that different from pressing 't'?
@wolverian 't' maps to 'Go To File...'.  I'm looking for a way to do a content search within the current repo, ideally as simply as pressing a single key.
@pvande Ah, I see. That would be useful.
A way to indicate that your fork is the "official" one. You could call it the "Conch" and have a "Conch request" to ask someone to pass it to you. :)

Notifications 2.0 — Small menu on click of nav notification number (think Facebook); Mark notification as read when viewing the commit/item the notification is about (e.g. new comments—I already read them!); Prettify the full notifications list page; Remove/enhance the paging on the full notifications page (it's cumbersome); Custom notification events (e.g. notify me when this repo is committed to by this user—pie in the sky, I know).

I want to be able to create a pull request from a patch (from git format-patch). it's kinda overkill to fork+create new branch+push when the diff is a one-liner, but it *is* nice to have the pull request view.
@h3h that was a lot of exactly one thing :-)
A better way to organize my repos. Like folders
@tbeseda or states: "I'm actively working on / using these" or "archived"
@catsby something like http://stillmaintained.com/ ?
One feature that I'd love is the ability to attach pull requests to existing issues.
User and Repository Status Messages - e.g. "I'm on vacation until yyyy-mm-dd" or "I'm no longer maintaining this, use something else instead!"
@pvande project description?
@kennethreitz Not really the same thing; contrary to my example, I'm really looking for something a bit more transient.
I'ld like a way to force UTF-8 for my README.mkd.
@bwinton: that's probably an issue on your end, the whole website is served utf-8. If you've got encoding problems, it's probably your editor saving the file weird
Improve issues system (allow hashtags to tag, @mentions to notify coworkers, parse @TODO from the code base, ...)
At least one free private repo...
A mobile version of the site.
A file size column.
@nicoulaj if they did that people would just sign up for multiple accounts instead of paying
@dasch i don't think a mobile version would be that great, i rather them focus energy into a github official iphone app and android app
Easier way to get to compare view. I always end up manually making a url.

For the bug trackers that are already supported through service hooks, replace the issues page with data from the tracker. Or even simpler, make that tab be configurable to point to a third party tracker.
@pvande This exists. Press T.
Improved issue system with awesome integration.
@dryan: THIS! (or as stated above make the issue tracker usable)
@JustinCampbell As stated earlier, 't' maps to 'Go To File...'. I'm looking for a way to do a content search within the current repo, ideally as simply as pressing a single key.
turns out the one thing I was going to ask for already works. You guys rock!
@dryan the free private repo could be a reward based on activity/numbers of forks/followers/etc.
@nicoulaj @dryan github is supposed to be social and if everyone had a free repo that is cutting out the main mission of github so I disagree no free private repos

How about some way to subscribe to a project's issue tracker so new posts/comments are sent via email. It would be nice to have some way to view a list of the subscribed issue trackers as well. This would completely replace the need for mailing lists for me.
It's been said above, but it's worth echoing: clone stats.
I think it would be awesome to group notifications in your news feed by project/day. there's so much noise in there that it's hard to be useful
octocat having a side kick . :P. Actually I don't have any suggestions. github is awesome :) anything extra would be awesome too :)
how about ditching the famfamfam icons for something more polished? they stick out like a sore thumb
Detecting prolog files. Maybe by checking the first line for a kind of shebang?
More drinking!
I look forward to seeing how many of these suggestions are actually addressed by the new issues changes.
replace the issue tracker already it's terrible
@holman haha!
Search.  They should integrate IndexTank ( http://www.indextank.com/ )
A way for maintainers (or users to collaboratively) to curate the Network Graph
i am newbie on convore and it my fiest message

As people have said the search is not very good. I have done a proof of concept that searches github & allows sorting (forks, watchers, name, activity etc). Let me know what you think http://bit.ly/i0N7ST
Filters on dashboard. Would like to be able to follow a user but not a specific fork or wiki-edits etc.

I think it's been said before (perhaps a few times), but I'd love for a more personal feed, so I only see what I'm interested in (ie tags). Also perhaps grouping your followers gists. Sometimes a follower can submit and edit a gist 5+ times in short periods. I'd also love the ability to create a pull request from a patch so I wouldn't have to fork every time

I for one find to "new repository" button a bit unreachable where it's currently placed. Don't get me wrong, once in the page where the button is it's quite visible, however to me makes more sense also having the button in my dashboard.

The ONLY thing that I really want right now is the ability to add a separate email address to be associated with the "organization" I'm a part of. I hate having all notifications go to my personal email address. It makes me cry everyday.
iPhone application capable of showing feed, diffs, push notifications for watched repos, nfc for adding someone as a collaborator or forking a repo, etc
Maybe +1 -1 buttons so this stops happening: https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/264#issuecomment-991072 / https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/pull/42
It would be awesome if I had 'status' on the issues. Like 'assigned' 'started' 'finished' 'delivered' 'accepted' 'rejected'
nevermind, that was solved with labels :P
I would like to see the ability to allow only fast-forward commits on important branches. On larger teams the idea that we're one mistyped `git push -f` away from losing commits on master is scary.
I would like to disable the graphs for our organization b/c of the reasons listed here: http://support.github.com/discussions/graphs/215-disabling-graphs
I would like to add the ability to block a user from constantly adding me to his projects, so I can stop having dicks shoved in my face!
+1 for user blocking. I'd love to remove trolls from my code
Per-repo privileges for organization teams
wow. this is eye-opening. These are awesome looking tools!
email notifications on commits. i can't believe this doesn't exist already.
there's the email hook.. is that not what you want?
Per-organization email address overrides.  Getting my professional org emails delivered to my personal inbox is annoying, even if it can be filtered around.
proper Prolog support. my Prolog repos are identified as being Perl *sad_face*

The ability to add line comments for code reviews on things other than commits. We periodically review sections of our code and we can't use the commit-based comment system. Another alternative would be to create a review request, like a pull request for bundling up changes into a set for consideration.
@jesseh What would happen to the comments when that piece of code (on that line) changed?
I'd love the option to view diffs in side-by-side format.
@jesseh: use pull request comments
a grep-like feature for repo could be useful
@locks Do you use .pl or .pro extensions? Does it make a difference?
@dideler I do use the .pl extension, but the thing is that prolog doesn't even show up on https://github.com/languages
@injekt The comments could go away with the line, similar to the way that blame works. In other words the comments would still be related to a commit but readable and writable in the source tree.
@technoweenie I was not able to get pull request comments to work for a private repo. Any suggestions?
pay github $5 extra per month to add my google analytics key to all my org's repos as in http://bit.ly/dkPbek
@seamusabshere omg yes

This is probably on you guys' list, but the dashboard seriously needs some love. The news feed actually isn't so bad -- a while back I unwatched everyone and I only watch people I want to show up on my news feed -- for the rest I use codeshelver. Otherwise, the dashboard isn't very useful to me. So one thing I'd like to see is pending pull requests -- I'm not so great at remembering what people have sent me, and there's no easy way to get that info in one list.
@mcmire https://github.com/dashboard/pulls/public
@jesseh you can comment on the combined diff for pull reqs.  We use that feature heavily
I'd love to see a solution to the fork-with-the-same-name problem. Who do I need to take that up with?
It would be great to get an answer soon-ish, because the Symfony2 community is busy breaking all their repo names to work around this... (foo/Bar -> foo/FooBar)
@bobthecow I must have missed this, care to explain?
Maybe I'm just overlooking this, but I'd love to have a view of all the issues that are assigned to me across all repos
I'd like to see a news feed like page for an individual repo - combination of commits, wiki, issues, pulls, etc.
I'd like bookmarks and follows. Repos like Django and Node just flood my news feed.
@bradwright It's unofficial, but Codeshelver is quite slick. http://codeshelver.com/
The LaTeX support in the Wikis could use a bit of work..
It would be nice if user organizations were listed on the profile page.

I want a better interface managing organization team members: rather than an autocomplete input (recall), show me a list of all organization members with a checkbox beside each (recognition). P.S. You guys are cool.
The network graph would be much easier to use on projects with lots of forks if it were zoomable.
"P.S. You guys are cool." +1
@nicoulaj that's a cool idea.
better design for gists
RSS feed for issues?

Spring cleaning of your stale forks is a sucky chore, and I wish more people did it once in awhile. Much of the onus is always going to be on the user side I guess, but it could be pretty awesome if you guys cooked up a nice web-based git-wtf type of view with quick access to a 'delete repo' button.
Another thing that might ease the clicky-clicky pain would be `hub fork -d` on the CLI, but I'll file that under could-put-my-money-where-my-mouth-is-and-implement-myself :-)
folders or categories to organise watched repos

fwiw, one of the biggest pains I currently experience (if you can call it a pain) is that commit comments on commits inside a PR aren't treated the same as PR diff comments.  In particular, the lack of a diff in the PR overview.  It would be nice since I have a hard time teaching people the difference (*cough* @niran *cough*). :-)
This: https://convore.com/github/listing-contributions/

The News feed and Notification feed is to noisy, cluttered and hard to read.
I never read it because it's to cumbersome to digest.

I'd love to see some improvement in those areas.

The News feed and Notification feed is to noisy, cluttered and hard to read.
I never read it because it's to cumbersome to digest.

I'd love to see some improvement in those areas.
The News feed in particular needs some love. My choices are either don't use my news feed, or don't watch any busy projects (certainly don't watch rails/rails).
I'd love to have my news feed say "rails/rails changed in the past 8 hours. 2 issues, 1 pull request, 23 comments. See more >>"

@jayferd: vim-mode --- it can can be trivial ;-) If github provided plain textboxes everywhere (instead of javascript-editors), you could use the ItsAllText https://github.com/docwhat/itsalltext plugin and use REAL vim (or emacs, or anything else). Just a teeny tiny textbox for IAT to notice, please!
Would be good to be able to watch/follow an issue to be notified when it's updated.
@Rolo: that makes me think of using a distributed issue tracker that works with git: http://www.cs.unb.ca/~bremner/blog/posts/git-issue-trackers/ when you pull, you'll get all new issues
@Rolo https://img.skitch.com/20111028-p228fy279dn5y3tcehd624pfgq.png
I would like Pull Requests to have an "Undo" feature.  Please see the paragraph titled, "#1 - ANYTHING IN THE MASTER BRANCH IS DEPLOYABLE" from  http://scottchacon.com/2011/08/31/github-flow.html
@chipcastle don't undo — just don't merge :D
@arbales - I wish it was that easy. :)

@tekkub Holy. Crap. I've been wishing for that functionality for a long time, and it's been there all along?! Maybe your UI guys can investigate if that option is overlooked by everyone, or just "special" users like me.
Preview option for gists.
Flattr buttons!
@jonesy pull requests

I'd like to see something I'll call 'real code reviews'. Let me actually click a button that says "Create a code review", and then invite people (github usernames) to review the code at a particular tag, commit, etc. Those people needn't be otherwise associated with the project. Then, the reviewers get the ability to pass or fail the review based on the objectives I've laid out in the description of the code review, in addition to the existing interactivity features. I just feel like people are calling the mere ability to comment on lines in a commit 'code review', and, well... it's just not.
@tekkub - please read my post. No, really.

one (hopefully) small feature : adding the number of repo viewers for each fork in the network graph viewer. for very forked projects, it can provide a glimpse into who might be more relevant to the project. (ex: defunkt/jquery-pjax/network )
@kneath I want a yak-shaving emoji. :bear: :scissors: doesn't cut it.
There's nothing better than bear scissors.  Screw yaks.

Toggling inline viewing of full extended commit messages on pull request pages. I think of commit messages as a channel of communication that, especially in a distributed team, is often where I give rationale for a change, so that's useful information for code reviews. If someone's entire line of reasoning is flawed, it's obvious that their code needs to be reworked without scrutinizing diffs.
